Award.AwardTitle: A Framework for Multiscale/Multiphysics Mathematical Modeling of Cerebral Aneurysm Rupture
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cerebral aneurysm (CA) is a diseased dilatation of an intracranial artery, and its rupture is the leading cause of subarachnoid bleeding. However, the mechanisms behind aneurysm formation, growth and rupture remain an enigma. While the current clinical technology cannot yet provide a lot of mechanistic details of these processes in vivo, many efforts have been devoted in modeling the biomechanics of the cerebral aneurysms. Specifically, numerical simulations have elucidated some of the physics associated with the arterial wall damage and aneurysm rupture. The proposed work aims to provide a multiphysics/multiscale mathematical model along with a numerical framework to understand the mechanism of cerebral aneurysm rupture. The new knowledge will be introduced into both graduate and undergraduate level courses. The resultant software will be ready for classroom use as friendly and free opensource routines for instructors and students.

This project aims to develop a new methodology for addressing fundamental open questions in multiscale and multiphysics modeling of brain aneurysms, and to study the interactions between the arterial wall and the blood flow with an emphasis on simulating the rupture phenomena. To be specific, the computational domain is composed of three regions: the fluid (blood) simulated as incompressible Newtonian flow, the fracture solid (aneurysm fundus wall) modeled by the nonlocal peridynamic theory, and the solid (arterial wall) described by a viscoelastic model. These three subregions will be numerically coupled to each other with proper interface boundary conditions. In preliminary work, the PI has: (1) developed new schemes for fluid-structure interaction (FSI) to stabilize and accelerate the coupling between the fluid solver and the classical solid solver; (2) designed an efficient long-term integration method for fractional-order PDEs (FPDEs) and found that the fractional order might serve as an indicator for the aneurysm wall strength; (3) investigated the Dirichlet-Dirichlet boundary condition for the peridynamic-classical theory coupling. In the next three years, the PI will work on both theoretical and numerical aspects. For the theoretical part, new models will be addressed to describe the viscoelastic behavior of the arterial walls and to capture the material failure near the aneurysm fundus. Regarding the numerical effort, high-performance computational tools based on high-order continuous/discontinuous Galerkin methods will be developed, which could accurately simulate the new models as well as provide a coupling framework for problems composed of heterogeneous domains with multiscale/multiphysics dynamics. Technically, the PI will: (1) further validate the fractional-order PDE models that better describe the viscoelastic behavior of cerebral aneurysm walls; (2) for the first time develop two-component peridynamic theory for modeling the aneurysm rupture, and develop high-order numerical solvers for this model based on the discontinuous Galerkin method; (3) design partitioned approaches for coupling the 3D continuum formulations of peridynamics and classical theory, by investigating proper mathematical interface conditions directly derived from conservation laws. The coupling techniques the PI has investigated in preliminary work (FSI coupling) would also be adopted into the multiscale coupling problem here. This project is co-funded by the Computational Mathematics Program of the Division of Mathematical Sciences, the BioMAPS Initiative and the Biomedical Engineering program of the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems Division (CBET).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cerebral aneurysm (CA) is a diseased dilatation of an intracranial artery, and its rupture is the leading cause of subarachnoid bleeding. However, the mechanisms behind aneurysm formation, growth, and rupture remain an enigma. This project aims to provide a mathematical model along with a numerical framework for cerebral aneurysm, with the ultimate goal of advancing the knowledge on the mechanism of aneurysm rupture. The research component of this project is also tightly integrated with the educational goal, by introducing the new knowledge into both graduate and undergraduate level courses and organizing local high-performance computing workshops to promote the engagement of under-represented groups.

For the intellectual merits, the PI has developed new mathematical theories and the corresponding numerical tools for multiscale and multiphysics modeling of brain aneurysms, and has studied the interactions between the arterial wall and the blood flow with an emphasis on simulating the rupture phenomena. The outcomes can be categorized into two interrelated parts: the development of new material models to describe the complex behavior of aneurysm walls, and the development of robust numerical methods to simulate the aneurysm growth and rupture procedure.

On the modeling side, to describe the complex behavior of aneurysm walls two new nonlocal models have been developed. Firstly, to model the viscoelastic constitutive laws of arterial wall mechanics, the PI numerically studied fractional PDEs that naturally model the continuous relaxation properties of soft tissue, and for the first time employed them to simulate long-term flow-structure interactions for patient-specific brain aneurysms. Second, to model the arterial wall damage procedure, the PI has employed the nonlocal peridynamic theory which can naturally describe fracture of materials. Moreover, new peridynamic formulations have been developed for applying physically consistent traction-type boundary conditions, so as to model the material damage induced by hydrodynamic stresses from blood flows.

On the numerical side, new numerical methods and new coupling strategies were designed for the multiscale and multiphysics modeling. For the fractional PDEs, a high-order fast convolution method was developed, which improves the numerical solver efficiency and enables its application in long-time simulations with complex patient-specific aneurysm geometries. For peridynamics and the general nonlocal models, the PI has developed a new meshfree method with an optimization-based quadrature rule, which was shown to have high-order convergence to the nonlocal analytical solution and preserve the correct local limit as the nonlocal interaction region and the numerical resolution sizes vanish simultaneously. Since the aneurysm rupture is a multiscale and multiphysics problem composed of heterogeneous domains, novel coupling schemes were developed in this project. To model the material failure near the rupture region while still sustaining the solver efficiency in the other regions, peridynamics--classical continuum model coupling strategies were developed. In regions where material failure is expected to initiate, the meshfree formulation based on the peridynamic theory is employed. In the rest of the problem domain, the material is modeled by the classical elastic theory, and numerically discretized with the finite element method. The two solvers communicate with each other by exchanging interface boundary conditions. Based on a novel nonlocal Robin-type boundary condition, the PI developed an explicit and robust local-to-nonlocal coupling strategy which was numerically verified on heterogeneous and complicated domains. Moreover, to simulate the interactions between aneurysm walls and the blood flows, new fluid-structure interaction algorithms were designed. Particularly, the PI has developed two immersed-type schemes where the structure and fluid are coupled on unfitted meshes, so as to handle large deformation and the possible topological change of the fluid domain once rupture occurs.

For the broader impacts, the developed models and numerical tools not only result in a computational framework for the study of aneurysm rupture, but also provide mathematical theory and a powerful computational software for a wide range of physical and biological applications. For instance, the developed fluid--structure interaction coupling strategy was employed to study the interaction between blood flows and heart valves, and the meshfree formulation for peridynamics was also employed in brittle fracture mechanics to study the crack initiation, growth, and branching of glass. For the education component, new courses have been introduced at Lehigh University on both undergraduate and graduate levels, and two undergraduate students from under-represented groups have been trained as summer research assistants in this project. To further promote the retention of female students and researchers from Lehigh, local high school, and neighboring colleges, an annual high-performance computing workshop was organized. This workshop has provided an opportunity for participants to get familiar with popular parallel programming technologies, and gave them a platform to interact with active researchers from academia and industry. After the workshop, the participants responded very positively, feeling encouraged to utilize or further pursue HPC knowledge in their research/work projects, and most of the participants showed strong desires to register in the future workshops and continue their studies in the scientific computing area.
